page.title: 05LANDSCAPE at Blindcrake
page.content: Blindcrake is situated in a geolog- ically interesting area on the North Western edge of the Lake District National Park. Surrounding rocks include limestone and basalt as rev- ealed in Ghyll Yeat. The field system goes back hundreds of years as evidenced by their long, narrow nature. This situation is not likely to change in the forseeable future as the 12 local farms do not own adjacent fields but appear to have them scattered at random! High ground (over app.160 m) remains uncultivated and is used as rough grazing although the limestone quarry, NGR 148362, is eating into a large area. There are several old limekilns in the area and their associated quarries, (best preserved at NGR 142343, 159353 and 144357).
